International 3-7 Deng Xiaoping appeared on TV with a group of nine other top officials, apparently resolving the question of who runs China. He expressed no remorse for the killing of hundreds, perhaps thousands, of civilians. Page 1 China names a culprit 5 Shanghai protesters defiant 7 Tale of a young victim in Beijing reflects a broken land 7 Rockier U.S.-China relations are emerging as the Bush Administration grapples with the question of how to relate with the hard-liners who have taken control in Beijing. 5 Chinese students at U.S. universities are ignoring the library and lab in favor of a task they consider most crucial: relaying information to keep the democracy movement alive. 6 Moynihan is booed off stage at Chinese protest at the U.N. 6 Travelers cancel China trips 6 A top Salvadoran was assassinated as he left his house. No one immediately took responsibility for slaying the official, the top civilian adviser to the new President. 1 The Soviet congress ended its session of 13 days with Andrei Sakharov saying the assembly had failed in their main task, to wrest control from the Communist Party elite. 1 Ethnic riots in Uzbekistan continue, Moscow reported. Gunfire has wounded scores of people, and troops are hard pressed to rout the mobs of Uzbek marauders hunting down the Meskhetian minority. 3 Lech Walesa plans to urge legislators backed by Solidarity not to join the Polish Government. He said the trade union seeks ''not to rule, but only to exercise control, and to broaden democracy and freedom.'' 3 A U.N. resolution assailing Israel for its policies in the occupied territories was vetoed by the United States in the Security Council. 3 Japan's leader has become ensnared by allegations of a sexual relationship four years ago with a former geisha who now charges him with ''immoral'' behavior. 4 Federal prosecutors file civil suit against Marcoses 3 The fifth world AIDS meeting closed with a discoverer of the AIDS virus reporting preliminary results of a new test that might help monitor the infection in a person. 32 National 8-11, 28 Toxic chemicals were discharged twice from the Rocky Flats Plant, in Colorado, into two creeks leading to metropolitan drinking water supplies in Denver, according a Justice Department affidavit. 1 A takeover artist, Paul Bilzerian, was convicted of nine counts of securities fraud, conspiracy and making false statements to the Government, in the first verdict of the Government's Wall Street inquiry. 1 James Watt said he got larger fees as a private consultant than had previously been reported and he acknowledged that his lobbying activities were not limited to the Department of Housing and Urban Development. 1 Changes in campaign finance rules, including a ban on most contributions to candidates by political action committees, are being planned in a Bush proposal, officials said. 1 A cut in sulfur dioxide emissions by public utilities, the chief source of acid rain, will be urged by President Bush as part of an amending of the Clean Air Act, officials say. 10 Development of the Stealth bomber would move forward despite its cost and strong Congressional opposition, the new Secretary of the Air Force, Donald Rice, said. 10 O.M.B. proposes reversal in data policy favoring private sector 28 The Bush news-conference style has turned out to be determindly different - in where the lectern stands and how the questions are answered -from the style of his predecessor, Ronald Reagan. 11 In Ronald Reagan's first trip abroad, the former President will travel to Britain and France this weekend. Friends say he has slipped comfortably into California life. 8 Prices at the producer level jumped nine-tenths of 1 percent in May, the Government reported. Although the rise was much bigger than expected, analysts cited special factors. 35 Rates fall; bonds rally 38 Virginians will nominate a black, Lieut. Gov. L. Douglas Wilder, today to be the Democratic candidate for governor. If elected, he would be the first black governor in any state. 8 To promote integration in Ohio cities, the state has distributed millions in low-interest loans to whites who buy houses in black areas and to blacks who buy houses in white areas. 8 Failed responsibility to the Indians is the subject of a report being prepared by a Senate panel. 10 U.S. would compensate non-Japanese war internees 8 Regional 29-32 Ten sermons about blacks and AIDS will be delivered this weekend in New York City, breaking what the clergymen say is silence about the disease's threat to minorities. 29 Soviet and American veterans of wars in Afghanistan and Vietnam met Thursday to talk about some things they have in common, like coming home from a futile war. 29 The first Bangladeshi to graduate at the top of her class in New York City, Magdalene Gomes, will leave Washington Irving High School as part of a diverse student group. 29 Mayor Koch's small campaign group for what seems like a daunting bid for a fourth term is far from the juggernaut that helped him amass huge victory margins in 1981 and 1985. 29 Lauder spotlights death penalty 31 Charged with diverting $1 million to his own bank account by using a loophole in a New York City computerized accounting system, a $39,000-a-year accountant was arrested at a motel in Coral Gables, Fla. 31 The mayoral election in Jersey City, to be held on Tuesday, pits Gerald McCann, a former Mayor, against Glen Cunningham, the first black to have a chance to become mayor. 30 13 Newarks celebrate name 30 The retrial of a murder suspect, Thomas Ryan, began in Riverhead, L.I., with opening statements and three witnesses, but without the prosecution's critical piece of evidence: a confession. 31 A judge orders more medical tests for Larry Davis 31
